Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Training in Basic and Applied Psychological Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is funded from the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program in the SBE Directorate. As such, it has both scientific and societal benefits, and it integrates research and education. Statistics from the NSF and the American Psychological Association indicate continual under-representation of African Americans, Hispanics, Asian Americans, Native Americans, and individuals with disabilities in the field of psychology. REU site at Baruch College offers advanced research training to undergraduate students who attend Baruch College, colleges within the City University of New York (CUNY), and other educational institutions in the New York metropolitan area. Baruch College and CUNY in general boast a diverse student body. Although the recruitment is open to any NSF eligible undergraduate students, this program is designed to increase the representation of minority, low-income, first generation college students, and disabled students in scientific psychology. Specifically, the program does the following: 1) identify early promising minority, disabled, and economically disadvantaged students throughout the New York metropolitan area, 2) increase psychological scientists exposure to cultural and minority issues in psychological research, 3) prepare REU students for advanced graduate training in psychology and ultimately for careers in academic settings, and 4) develop a pipeline to provide a pool of talented and diverse undergraduate students to become the research scientists of the future.

REU students conduct independent research under the supervision of an REU faculty member working in an area that matches the student's expressed interests (e.g., developmental psychology, clinical psychology, social psychology, or industrial/organizational psychology). Each student focuses on planning and executing studies with the intention of presenting papers at professional conferences and submitting manuscripts to peer-reviewed journals. Specifically, REU students develop research questions and hypotheses that are grounded in the literature. In order to answer these newly developed research questions and hypotheses, REU students design research protocols and plan data collection. Then, REU students learn via hands-on experience the value of statistical analysis, use of statistical software to draw inferences about the data, and presentation skills to disseminate the findings gained in their research. Alongside with the conduct of their research projects, REU students complete a series of structured activities aimed at preparing them to apply to graduate school. These activities, such as attending weekly seminars, participating at colloquium in the field of psychology, listening to invited guest speakers from graduate program admission offices, are coordinated by the Baruch College REU program.

Institution.Name: CUNY Baruch College
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

ProgramReference.Text: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes achieved in the triennium 2016-2019 are in line with the merits and broader impacts described in the final report.

 

Please find below a select sample of:

- Baruch College NSF-REU Conferences.

- National Conference Presentations and Publications.

-- Graduate school admissions among our REU participants.

 

 

Agenda for the Research Experience for Undergraduates Spring Conference Funded by the National Science Foundation

2017

"The Effects of Temporal Priming on Environmental Attitudes" by Calvin Rong from Dr. Engle-Friedman’s Lab

 “Matthew Effect: Gender Differences in Spatial Ability” by Rachel Rodriguez and Courtney Wheeler from Dr. Scherbaum’s Lab

 “The Role of Language Simplification on Jury Decision-making in Civil Court Cases” by Jessica Dudzinska from Dr. Park’s Lab 

 “Idiographic Everyday Problem Solving in Adult Development” by Matthew Liu from Dr. Artistico’s Lab

"Good Quality Sleep Impacts Perceived Social Distance and Energy" by Brian Tang from Dr. Engle-Friedman’s Lab

 “Effects of Demonstrative Evidence on Mock Jurors’ Legal Judgement” by Dafna Yacobian from Dr. Park’s Lab

"Framing and Global Warming" by Godly Alcindor from Dr. Engle-Friedman’s Lab

 “Future Resilience in Older Adults Based on Idiographic Everyday Problem Solving” by Karol Trochez-Zuniga from Dr. Artistico’s Lab

What underlies jurors' decision making - by Lisa Dazzell from Dr. Park’s Lab

2018

"Environmental Communication" by Kiranpreet Sawheny from Dr. Engle-Friedman’s Lab

 “Ignorance Isn’t Bliss: How Knowing Our Strengths Can Improve Our Effectiveness” by Kelsey Luks, Ye Sil Chen, Sofia Wyman, and Alba DelaCruz

 “Pro-Environmental Behaviors and Personality” by Zuzanna Osiecka from Dr. Engle-Friedman’s Lab

"The effect of mortality salience on prejudice, racism, and leadership preferences" by Christine Chueng and Shanell Bailey from  

 “A Test Retest Reliability Study” by Kristina Horne from Dr. Engle-Friedman’s Lab

 “Effects of Demonstrative Evidence and Instructions on Mock Jurors' Legal Judgment” by Ann Privorotskiy from Dr. Parks’s Lab

"Doing the Math with the Matthew Effect " by Regina Agassian and Katie Mahabir from Dr. Scherbaum’s Lab

 

2019

"Lights, Camera, Faking: Comparing Warning Derterrants to Prevent Faking." by Colleen Corpuz, Vicotria Kui, Sabriuna Wu from Dr. Scherbaum’s Lab

“Why are pro-environmental behaviors difficult? ” by Natalie Cruz from Dr. Engle-Friedman’s Lab

 “Implicit and Explicit Biases and Intergroup Relations” by Sumayyah Uddin from Dr. Park’s Lab

 “The Effects of Naps on Effort ” by Kyla Jones from Dr. Engle-Friedman’s Lab

"The Relationship Between Mortality Salience and Helping Behavior" by Maria O’Brien from Dr. Park’s Lab 

“The Effect of Climate Change on Reproductive Decisions.” By Jenna Tipaldo from Dr. Parks’s Lab

"Awareness of Emotions Leads  to Self-Efficacy Among College Student" by Amy Lee & Emily DeLaCruz from Dr. Artistico’s Lab

 

 

 Select Presentations and Publications:

Horne, K.A., Lee, M., Osiecka, Z., Sawhney, K., Jones, K., Engle-Friedman, M. (2019, March). Students’ Attribution of Responsibility for Combating Climate Change and Its Relationship to Frequency of Sustainable Behaviors. Eastern Psychological Association, New York, New York.  

Understanding Individuals’ Everyday Problem Solving (EPS) Ability: The Advantages of Idiographic Methods and a Knowledge-and-Appraisal Model of Personality Architecture Liu M., Cha Y.S., Delacruz, A., Luks, K., Wyman, S. (2018). Poster presented at the annual meeting of the Association for Psychological Science, San Francisco, CA.

Larsen, C., Fong, M., & Park, J. (2018). Effects of explicit and implicit brand preferences on legal judgments. Poster presented at the annual meeting of the Association for Psychological Science, San Francisco, CA.

Scherbaum, C., DeNunzio, M., Oliveira, J. & Ignagni, M. (2017). Race and Cultural Differences on Predictors Commonly Used in Employee Selection and Assessment. In B. Passmore, H. Goldstein, & E. Pulakos’ (Eds.) The Handbook of the Psychology of Recruitment, Selection, and Retention (pg. 400-421). Wiley-Blackwell.

 

-- Artistico, D., Cervone, D. P., & Montes Garcia, C. (2019). My Problems are Solvable:Idiographic Methods Offset Age Differences in Interpersonal Problem Solving among Young, Middle-Aged, and Older Adults. Frontiers: Social Cognition, 10(276), 1-9.

-- Scherbaum, C., DeNunzio, M., Oliveira, J. & Ignagni, M. (in press). Race and Cultural Differences on Predictors Commonly Used in Employee Selection and Assessment. In B. Passmore, H. Goldstein, & E. Pulakos’ (Eds.) Wiley-Blackwell.

 

 

GRADUATE SCHOOL ADMISSIONS

- Nnekora Wilson- M/S Program in I/O Psychology at Baruch College.

 - Joel Engleman – Ph.D. program in clinical at Bowling Green State University.

 - Virginal Milieris, Boston University School of Social Work.

 - Weiwen Nie the i/O Ph. D. program at Virginia Tech.

 - Nazia Denese- Teachers College - Columbia University.

 - Tiffany Narain Master's in School Psychology Adelphi University, NY.

 - Kiley Cappetta Medical Program at the University of Virginia.

- Lisa Caraballo-  Fordham University's MS Program in Clinical Research Methods.

- Amy Lee- MHC Program Hunter College.

- Kelsey Luks- Master’s in Clinincal Psychology Fordham University, NY.

- Zuzanna Osiecka – Master’s Program in Psychology at the New School.

- Jessica Dudenza – MHC Hunter College.

- Karol Trocher– MHC Hunter College.

- Alba DeLaCruz– Nursing School GWU.
